position.marginalia_text: Quicquid mille Diaboli dixerint; Ironia est
angelus coeli. Agant illi Furias tragicas: / tu ride comicè: et rem age ipsam. Viuitur ingenio.

marginalia.translation: Whatever a thousand devils will have said, Irony is an angel from heaven. While the former stirs up tragic frenzies, you laugh comically and do the thing itself. One lives by one's abilities.

position.marginalia_text: Sine la[e]titia, vita miseria: sine auda[c]ia, homo bestia.

marginalia.translation: Without happiness, life is a misery. Without daring, man is a beast.

position.marginalia_text: Quoties tristis, toties miser: quoties timidus, toties bestia.

marginalia.translation: As often as he is sad, so often is he miserable. As often as he is timid, so often is he a beast.

position.marginalia_text: Degeneres, et pueriles animos Timor arguit.

marginalia.translation: Fear betrays degenerate and childish souls.
More excellent than the most excellent.
Always free, or else never great.
The sharp trainer repeats; he repeats.

position.marginalia_text: Non lectio, aut scriptio; sed quotidiana relectio, et repetitio est, qua[e] virum facit reuerâ virum: incessantem, et semper magis, magisq[ue] industrium.

marginalia.translation: Neither reading, nor writing, but daily re-reading and repetititon is that which, in reality, makes a man; a man who is unceasing and ever more and more diligent.

position.marginalia_text: = alios tenet, tenet neminem. Totus vir, solus vir.

marginalia.translation: He who keeps others, keeps no one. Only a man alone is completely a man.

position.marginalia_text: - tam necessaria acri actori, quàm panis quotidianus. Nunq[uam] nimis, quod

marginalia.translation: As necessary to the keen actor as daily bread. That which is never enough is never too much.
